revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2017}}
'''Shop fitting''' ('''shopfitting''') is the trade of fitting out [[retail]] and service [[Retailing|shops]] and [[Retailing|stores]] with equipment, fixtures and fittings. The trade applies to all kinds of outlets from small corner shops to [[hypermarket]]s. A '''shop fitter''' executes planning, [[design]]s shop layout and installs equipment and services. A shop fitting [[business entity|firm]] typically incorporates professional expertise in [[interior design]], manufacturing of [[bespoke]] furniture, signage and fittings (with own or [[outsourcing|outsourced]] facilities) and purchasing of retail equipment.
A shop fitting cycle begins with a survey and measurement of available space and preparing design drawings for submission to the client. Alternatively, the client may have their own drawings prepared by an independent interior designer. The shop fitter arranges for purchase of standard equipment and merchandise or production of bespoke furniture, delivers and physically installs them—until the shop is ready for daily operation.
There are different requirements to the different branches and types of shop. [[Fashion]] shop design requires up-to-the-minute awareness of current trends in colour and style to create stores that will draw customers in.
==Systems== ''<nowiki/>'Shopfitting system''' refers to a product range made to satisfy the needs of shopfitters and ultimately retailers for display and [[merchandising]] goods. A shopfitting system can be adapted from combinations of standardized components for a particular retail application. A manufacturer would normally launch new shopfitting systems on a 2-year basis. Leading manufacturers would offer design oriented systems, followers would reinterpret them making the display solution achievable with as many as existing items as possible, hoping that retailers will choose their product because of the cheap price.
Shopfitting systems are usually connected to a "modular" concept, meaning that each item has more than one use. This economically goes into the rules of "network", where one element has the value of three, if added to another element, because 1x1=1 but 2x2=4: an extra item designed and compatible with others, has very high value.
== Shop Fitting Profession == '''Shop Fitting''' is a profession that involves the fitting of retail outlets like corner shops, department stores, convenience stores, supermarkets and hypermarkets with equipment, fixtures and fittings. It’s carried out by a shop fitter who executes all planning, design, layout and installation of equipment and services. A '''shop fitter''' brings interior design expertise and assists in the design of bespoke furniture, fittings and signage and also with the buying of retail equipment.
The process begins with a survey of the retail premises and measurement of available space. The next stage is the preparation of design, which is then submitted to the client for review and approval. Some clients provide their own design drawings that are prepared by another interior designer. Finally, the shop fitter arranges for the purchase of standard equipment and the production of the bespoke furniture, which is delivered and installed – ready for the shop operation.
Shop fitting is a precision orientated profession that requires intricacy and exceptional attention to detail in order to meet client requirements. Visual elements heavily impact customer behaviour hence why shop fitting is now at the forefront of attracting new customers to stores across the globe.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lake|first1=Dean|title=Shop Fitting|url=https://lakecontracts.co.uk/service/shop-fitting/|website=Lake Contracts|publisher=Lake Contracts}}</ref>
==References== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Shop Fitting}}
[[Category:Retailing]] [[Category:Design]] [[Category:Promotion and marketing communications]]

{{for|nightclub events with no speaking|Quiet Party}} {{for|2011 play by Lachlan Philpott|Silent Disco (play)}}
[[File:QuietClubbing Gatsby Party 4.08.16.jpg|thumb|QuietClubbing Gatsby Party in New York on April 8, 2016]] A '''silent disco''' or '''silent rave''' is an event where people dance to music listened to on wireless [[headphone]]s.<ref name="Oxford English Dictionary">{{cite web|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/silent+disco|title=silent disco - Definition of silent disco in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English}}</ref> Rather than using a [[speaker system]], music is broadcast via a radio transmitter with the signal being picked up by wireless headphone receivers worn by the participants. Those without the headphones hear no music, giving the effect of a room full of people dancing to nothing.
In the earliest days of silent discos, before 2005, there would be only one channel available to listen to music through. Over time, the technology moved along to where there were two, and later technology allowed for a third channel that three separate DJs could broadcast over at the same time.
Silent discos are popular at music festivals as they allow dancing to continue past noise curfews. Similar events are "mobile clubbing" gatherings, where a group of people dance to the music on their personal music players.
==History== [[Image:Silent house party san francisco.jpg|thumb|left|A silent house party in [[San Francisco, California]]]] An early reference in fiction is the 1969 Finnish science-fiction film ''Ruusujen Aika'' (''A Time of Roses''), where characters wear headsets during a party.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0138764/|title= IMDb "A Time of Roses"|publisher=|accessdate=|last=|first= | date=}}</ref>
The concept was used by eco-activists in the early 1990s, utilizing headphones at outdoor parties to minimize noise pollution and disturbance to the local wildlife.
In 1994, the [[Glastonbury Festival]] linked its on-site radio station to the video screen sited next to the Main Stage, allowing festival goers to watch late night [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] football and music videos on the giant screen after the sound curfew by using their own portable radios. The idea was the brainchild of the project manager from Proquip, who supplied the giant screen, and engineers from Moles Recording Studio in [[Bath, Somerset]], who were working with Radio Avalon.
In May 2000, [[BBC]] Live Music held a "silent gig" at [[Chapter Arts Centre]] in [[Cardiff]], where the audience listened to a band, Rocketgoldstar, and various DJs through headphones.<ref name="BBC Music Live events unfold">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/764290.stm|title=BBC News - ENTERTAINMENT - BBC Music Live events unfold|website=news.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In May 2002 artist Meg Duguid hosted ''Dance with me...'' a silent dance party at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago]] where she created an outdoor club installation complete with velvet ropes and glow rope in which a DJ spun a transmission to wireless headsets that audience members put on and danced to.<ref>http:</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Molzahn|first1=Laura|title=Summer Solstice Celebration|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/summer-solstice-celebration/Content?oid=908938|website=Chicago Reader|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://megduguid.com/section/149646-Dance-with-me.html|title=Dance with me...|website=megduguid.com}}</ref> Duguid threw a second dance party at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago]] the following year, entitled Dueling DJs where two DJS simultaneously spun two separate musical transmissions various wireless headsets that audience members put on and danced to. This performance was repeated the following year (2004) at the [[Chicago Cultural Center]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dueling DJs @ Cultural Center|url=http://www.gapersblock.com/slowdown/archives/2004/12/|website=Gapers Block: Slow Down Archive|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref>
The term "silent disco" has been in existence since at least 2005 with [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] advertising such an event that year with DJ’s [[Motion Potion]], Quickie Mart and DJ medi4 and headphones provided by KOSS.<ref>{{cite news | title =Boogie Nights: 'Silent disco' is making itself heard | first =Robin A. | last =Rothman | url =http://www.mtv.com/news/1504012/bonnaroo-kicks-out-the-jams-thanks-to-dave-matthews-john-mayer-and-bo-bice/ | newspaper =[[MTV]] | date =June 13, 2005 | accessdate =June 13, 2005 }}</ref> In the Netherlands, the traveling arts and culture festival De Parade already featured a "stille disco" [silent disco] earlier, for example in 2003. <ref>{{cite web|last1=Schmitz|first1=Jowi|title=Amsterdams Parade-publiek bekijkt zichzelf|url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2003/08/05/amsterdams-parade-publiek-bekijkt-zichzelf-7649080-a812311|website=NRC.nl|publisher=NRC|accessdate=21 May 2018|language=Dutch|date=5 August 2003}}</ref> Dutch DJs Nico Okkerse and Michael Minton have been described as "the pioneers ... in the legend of silent disco" because they started "stille disco" events in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carroll|first1=Robert|title=A quiet night out|url=https://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/music/a-quiet-night-out-1.499140|website=The National|publisher=The National|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=19 November 2008}}</ref> Okkerse claims his company 433fm.com "created Silent Disco in 2002"<ref>{{cite web|title=Nico Okkerse|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/nico-okkerse-0b0191b/|website=LinkedIn|publisher=LinkedIn|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> and its site does have photos from such events going back to at least 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Festival de Parade Museumpark|url=http://www.radio433.com/foto/detail.php?book=20030620&taal=|website=Radio433.com|publisher=433fm.com|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=2003}}</ref>
[[HUSHconcerts]] (previously, Silent Frisco) was the first company to produce a multi-city Silent Disco tour in 2008 with Silent Soundclash <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2008/jun/14/meltdownmassiveattack|title=Meltdown: Silent disco, big noise|last=Ojumu|first=Akin|date=2008-06-14|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref> kicking off at [[Winter Music Conference]] in Miami, followed by Atlanta, Athens, Savannah, Wilmington NC, Charlottesville Va, Baltimore, New York City, Syracuse, Pittsburgh and St. Louis. During this tour, the company became the first to produce American silent discos on a beach (Miami Beach) and a boat (the Rocksoff Cruise in New York Harbor).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jambands.com/news/2010/04/02/silent-soundclash-rana-eric-krasno-chapter-2-among-cruises-on-rocks-off-calendar|title=Silent Soundclash, RANA, Eric Krasno & Chapter 2 Among Cruises on Rocks Off Calendar|website=www.jambands.com|access-date=2017-01-24}}</ref>
The [[Oxford Dictionary Online]] added the term "silent disco" to their website in February 2011.<ref name="Oxford English Dictionary" /> As interest has increased, there has been a rise in the number of companies organizing parties and providing events with wireless headphones. Some companies have offered home kits.<ref name="craze">{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/6142360/Silent-disco-craze-spreads.html|title=Silent disco craze spreads|last=Johnston|first=Ian|date=6 September 2009|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=7 June 2010}}</ref>
==Mobile clubbing== Another type of silent party, known as mobile clubbing, involves the gathering of a group of people in an unconventional location to dance to music which they provide themselves via a [[Portable audio player|portable music device]], such as an [[MP3 player]], listened to on headphones. These [[flash mob]] gatherings may involve hundreds of people, transforming public spaces into temporary clubbing areas, in which dancers listen to their personal playlists. To an observer it would appear that the participants are dancing for no apparent reason. Mobile clubbing events are organized using mass-emails, word-of-mouth or [[social networking]] websites such as [[Facebook]], or a combination of these methods.
The first event, organised by London-based artists Ben Cummins (also founder of Pillow Fight Club) and Emma Davis, was at London's [[Liverpool Street Station]] in September 2003.<ref name="Mobile Clubbing website">[http://www.mobile-clubbing.com/Seedsprouts/MobileClubbing/Display/EventList.aspx?period=past Mobile Clubbing website] retrieved on 2009-02-28</ref> Over the next five months there were a further five events at other London train stations including [[London Waterloo railway station|Waterloo]], [[Charing Cross railway station|Charing Cross]] and [[London Bridge station|London Bridge]].<ref name="Mobile Clubbing Instructions">[https://web.archive.org/web/20070501081916/http://www.mobile-clubbing.com/eventsWeb/public/mobileclubbing/mcInstructions.aspx Mobile Clubbing Instructions] retrieved on 2007-05-01</ref> By the end of 2008 there had been more than twenty of these events at similar venues throughout London, mostly train station concourses or other public spaces that lend themselves to expressive dancing and rapid dispersal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=409998&in_page_id=1770|title=i-Pod flashmobbers dance in their hundreds at station|publisher=}}</ref>
An event in 2007 at [[London Victoria station|Victoria Station]], [[London]] involved 4,000 participants.<ref>{{cite news | title = 4,000 flash mob dancers startle commuters at Victoria | first = Tim | last = Stewart | work = [[Evening Standard]] | date = 2007-04-05 | accessdate = 2007-05-03 | url = https://www.standard.co.uk/news/4000-flash-mob-dancers-startle-commuters-at-victoria-7203786.html }}</ref> The event was broken up by police two hours later.
==Headphone concert== [[File:Flaming Lips - headphone concert poster.png|thumb|left|A Flaming Lips poster promoting "The World's First Headphone Concerts"]] A headphone concert is a [[live music]] performance where the audience, in the same venue as the performing artist, listens to the music through headphones.<ref name="plug2005">{{cite web|title=[:]plug[:] (2005)|url=http://deletist.info/|work=deletist.info |accessdate=2016-08-23| date=2005-08-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050924230826/http://deletist.info/|archivedate=2005-09-24}}</ref> The idea originated in 1997 when [[Erik Minkkinen]],<ref>[[:fr:Sister Iodine]]</ref><ref name="placard2005">{{cite web|title=the placard headphone festival|url=http://www.leplacard.org/|work=leplacard.org |accessdate=2005-10-26| date=2005-08-31 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051026233655/http://www.leplacard.org/|archivedate=2005-10-26}}</ref> an electronic artist<ref>{{cite web|url=http://v2.nl/archive/people/erik-minkkinen|title=Erik Minkkinen|website=V2_Institute for the Unstable Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/artist/76850-Erik-Minkkinen|title=Erik Minkkinen|website=Discogs}}</ref> from [[Paris]], streamed a live concert from his closet over the internet to three listeners in Japan.<ref name="wiredbyo">{{cite web|last=Axline|first=Keith|title=Fest Rocks With BYO Headphones|url=http://archive.wired.com/entertainment/music/news/2005/08/68682|work=Wired.com entertainment music news|publisher=wired magazine|accessdate=2016-08-23|date=2005-08-31|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160823160820/http://archive.wired.com/entertainment/music/news/2005/08/68682|archivedate=2016-08-23}}</ref> The concept led to a decentralized organization known as ''le placard'' ("the Cupboard"),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://translate.google.com/#fr/en/Placard|title=Google Translate|website=translate.google.com}}</ref> which allowed anybody to establish a streaming or listening room.<ref name="wiredbyo"/>
The first headphone concert taking place in front of a live audience took place March 20, 1999, at the [[South by Southwest]] festival in [[Austin, Texas]]. The American psychedelic band [[The Flaming Lips]] used an FM signal generator at the venue and handed out mini [[FM radio]] receivers and headphones to each member of the audience. A normal speaker system was also used so the sound could also be felt. This continued on their "International Music Against Brain Degeneration Revue" tour with mixed results, with technical problems including dead batteries and intoxicated audience members having trouble tuning to the correct frequency.<ref name="warner press archive">{{cite web|last=Booker|first=Scott|title=Partly Accurate Flaming Lips News|url=http://www.wbr.com/flaminglips/cmp/marnov99.htm|work=Archived News Relating To The Flaming Lips|accessdate=2013-02-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070329221215/http://www.wbr.com/flaminglips/cmp/marnov99.htm|archivedate=2007-03-29|df=}}</ref> Another headphone concert was performed in the [[Chapter Arts Centre]], [[Cardiff]] in April 2000 by [[Rocketgoldstar]].<ref name="BBC Music Live events unfold" />
Later headphone concerts used specially designed wireless 3-channel headphones, better in-house custom made transmitters and no speakers or any live PA in the venue. Major events hosting headphone concerts included the 2005 [[Glastonbury Festival]], [[2010 Shift Festival]] in Switzerland,<ref>{{cite web|last=Spirgi|first=Dominique|title=2010 Shift Festival english program|url=http://www.shiftfestival.ch/en/shift-2010/program/headphone-concerts/|work=2010 Shift Festival website|publisher=Shift Electronic Arts Festival Postfach CH-4023 Basel Switzerland|accessdate=2009-01-10}}</ref> the 2011-12 [[Van's Warp Tours]] across North America, [[Sensoria Music & Film Festival|Sensoria 2012]] in [[Sheffield, UK]], the 2012 [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]] in Tennessee and the [[Hoxeyville Music Fest]] in Michigan.<ref name="knoxnews.com">{{cite web|last=Brimer|first=Adam|title=Bonnaroo Silent Disco Day 1|url=http://www.knoxnews.com/photos/galleries/2012/jun/07/day-1-thursday-at-bonnaroo-2012/46908/|work=knox news|publisher=Knoxnews.com|accessdate=Dec 10, 2012}}</ref> In 2012, [[Kid Koala]] performed a "Space Cadet Headphone Concert tour" around the world.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://blogs.villagevoice.com/music/2012/04/kid_koala_space_cadet_headphone_experience_april_4_review.php | title = Live: Kid Koala's Space Cadet Headphone Experience Crashes In Brooklyn - New York - Music - Sound of the City | accessdate = 2013-02-21 | last = Mlynar | first = Phillip | date = 2012-04-05 | publisher = [[Village Voice]]}}</ref>
A variant of the headphone concert involves live bands competing for the audience, who are able to choose which band's frequency to receive. In August 2008, the first silent [[Battle of the Bands]] was held at [[Barfly (club)|The Barfly]] music venue in [[Cardiff]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thejoycollective.co.uk/blog/uncategorized/preview-silent-gig-featuring-kutosismuscle-club-and-others-barfly-wed-13th-august|title= Silent Gig featuring Kutosis/Muscle Club and others @ Barfly : Wed 13th August |publisher=Joy Collective|accessdate=2008-08-08|last=|first= | date=}}</ref> The event featured bands going directly head-to-head, with a stage at each end of the venue, allowing gig-goers to choose which group they wished to listen to.
==Silent theatre== Theatre and performance companies are now beginning to exploit silent disco technology as well. In 2009, with the help of SilentArena Ltd, Feral Productions began using an experimental approach – a mixture of narrative-led performance, [[sound art]] and guided exhibit. Their first performance, ''The Gingerbread House'', took the audience from The [[Courtyard, Hereford]] on a journey through a [[multi-storey car park]] in the centre of Hereford. In 2010, their second show, ''Locked (Rapunzel’s Lament)'', took place in a children’s playground, also in Hereford. Silent theatre techniques are now being used by companies in Liverpool, Birmingham and Glasgow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/leisure/reviews/4715331.Thinking_out_of_the_dramatic_box/ |title=The Gingerbread House breaks dramatic boundaries in Hereford |accessdate= |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |quote= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.herefordtimes.com/leisure/theatre/8383794.New_theatre_group___s_hoping_for_another_fairytale_ending_at_The_Courtyard_in_Hereford/ |title=Feral Productions' hoping for another fairytale ending at The Courtyard in Hereford |accessdate= |last= |first= |coauthors= |date= |format= |work= |publisher= |pages= |quote= }}</ref>
In 2015 [[Lincoln Center]] staged a production of the [[Rocky Horror Picture Show]] utilizing Quiet Events Headphones,<ref>{{cite web|title=Quiet Theater|url=https://quietevents.com/quiet-theater/|website=Quiet Events|publisher=Quiet Events|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref> where an audience wearing headphones could switch between the audio for the live performance and the soundtrack of the film version being projected behind it.<ref>{{Cite news|title = ‘Rocky Horror’ at Lincoln Center, With Headphones|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/10/movies/rocky-horror-in-central-park-with-headphones.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-08-09|access-date = 2015-09-25|issn = 0362-4331|first = Dave|last = Itzkoff}}</ref>
== Silent street shows == Street performers have used the concept as a solution to overcome bans on amplification and loudspeakers on the street. In 2016, Irish band [[Until April]] began using this for their shows on the street while touring in Germany and Switzerland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.advertiser.ie/galway/article/86139/galway-duo-find-novel-way-to-overcome-amplifier-bans-on-continental-europe|title=Galway duo find novel way to overcome amplifier bans on continental Europe|access-date=2016-07-21}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.efestivals.co.uk/info/silentdisco.shtml eFestivals guide to silent disco] *Study: Silent Disco Headphones for Multi-Elemental Creative Expression [http://www.silentdiscotheque.com/silentdiscopartyheadphones.pdf]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Silent Disco}} [[Category:Parties]] [[Category:Noise pollution]] [[Category:Music events]] [[Category:2000s fads and trends]] [[Category:Headphones]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/100Poders|100Poders]] ([[User talk:100Poders|talk]]) to last version by Yobot
differencing the art colony and the town it is in
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{tone|date=September 2012}} {{peacock|date=March 2013}} {{refimprove|date=September 2014}} }}
The '''Songzhuang art colony''' (simplified Chinese: 宋庄艺术区; traditional Chinese: 宋莊藝術區`; pinyin: Sòng zhuāng), located in Songzhuang Town of [[Tongzhou District, Beijing|Tongzhou]] (in the eastern suburbs of [[Beijing]]), is the most famous and biggest artist community in Beijing. More than 2,000 artists live there.
Originally representing the [[avant-garde]], the area now accommodates artists who paint in varying styles, ranging from the avant-garde to the academic. Sculptors and photographers also call the area home.
==The character of Songzhuang art colony==
The previously institutionalized and socially motivated art system produced many of the initial artists of the Chinese avant-garde. Were it not for the breakaway radicals of the last two decades, there simply would be no artistic community in Songzhuang, even if its present concerns are perhaps more of a monetary rather than a sociological nature. With a shift catering more towards the foreign market occurring in the 1980s, and the rise of the [[nouveau-riche]] at the beginning of the new century, today it is both the growing upper middle class in the cosmopolitan cities as well as foreign collectors and galleries that have become the prominent collectors of contemporary art in China, though one would have to be über-cynical to suppose that the creative process has become wholly money-orientated to the modern artist living here. Far from it, in fact, a spirit of [[idealism]], a “Songzhuang spirit” well and truly exists, and can even be examined from a historical perspective, where the roots of the artistic community can be traced back to Yuanmingyuan, the grounds of the [[Old Summer Palace]] in the north-east of Beijing. It was there that in the 1980s, like-minded free spirits congregated, living relatively poorly, though freely, escaping from the [[rat race]] and pressures of modern society. Artists arrived from all over China, celebrating a creative community and period of intense artistic exploration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://beijingtoday.com.cn/2013/10/songzhuang-remembers-20-years-cutting-edge-creation/ |title=Songzhuang remembers 20 years of cutting-edge creation |publisher=[[Beijing Today]] |date=27 Oct 2013 |accessdate=5 Jan 2014}}</ref>
==Searching for tranquility== A trend was established for artists to migrate away from the cities and to form their own communities such as the famous [[Beijing East Village]]. It brought far-reaching consequences for the Chinese avant-garde scene, as focus shifted away from the emerging capitalistic distractions and political pressures and opportunity was given in a tranquil environment for inner reflection and deep contemplation. However, problems arose once the community began attracting attention/notoriety from the media, gallery owners and other quarters, making artistic life more difficult as the once relaxed and free atmosphere came under closer scrutiny. The 1993 [[documentary]] ‘Seeking Dreams on the Verge’, by the director [[Zhang Jiarui]], explores these issues.
In an effort to preserve the spirit of the avant-garde, Fang Lijun, Zhang Huiping and Yue Minjun took the bold initiative in the spring of 1994 to relocate from Yuanmingyuan to the farming area of Songzhuang Township, located between the [[Chaobai]] and Wenyue rivers in [[Tongzhou District, Beijing|Tong County]], 20 km away from central Beijing. [[Liu Wei (artist)|Liu Wei]], Zhang Huiping, Wang Qiang and [[Gao Huijun]] were also in this first wave of artists to move. By the end of the year Yang Shaobin, Ma Ziheng, Zhang Jianqiang, Shao Zhenpeng, [[Liu Fenghua]], Zhang Mingqiang, [[Wang Qiuren]] and [[Yao Junzhong]] joined them. With the accompaniment of renowned art critic [[Li Xianting]], who later became known as “ the Godfather of Songzhuang ”, a quite formidable group of talent had succeeded in keeping the flame burning for Chinese avant-garde art.
Here, the old style farmhouses, many with a small front courtyards or gardens, proved an ideal living and working space for the artists, more of whom would subsequently arrive following the official closure of the Yuanmingyuan community in 1995, this being in some part due to the latter’s proximity to Beijing’s university district. The communal artistic lifestyle and essence of the avant-garde was preserved and remained intact amongst the tribulations, albeit by transplantation to Songzhuang.
==Today== About present day Songzhuang, native artist Cheng Da Qing said, “ The future of [[Chinese fine art]] is in Songzhuang ”. The artistic community now has over one thousand artists, centered mainly in the village of Xiaopu and spreading throughout Tuanli, Liuhe, [[Daxing]], Xindian, Lamazhuang, Renzhuang, Beisi, Baimiao and Xiaoyang. Painters, sculptors, photographers, writers, [[Conceptual art|conceptual]]/[[new media art]]ists and dreamers live side-by-side, the largest gathering of contemporary artists certainly in China if not in the world.
October 2005 saw the successful inauguration of an annual Songzhuang Art Festival, under the sponsorship of the Ministry of Culture, the Songzhuang Township Government, and the Songzhuang Art Promotion Society, when over six hundred works were shown along the 2 km main road in Xiaopu. The subsequent year’s festival used the newly constructed Songzhuang Art Museum and the East District Artistic Centre, strengthening Songzhuang's reputation as an arts community.
Travel to and from Beijing is convenient with local transport or taxi capable of making the journey in under an hour.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Tongzhou District, Beijing]] [[Category:Culture in Beijing]] [[Category:Chinese art]]

[[File:Giulio campagnola, l'astrologo.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Giulio Campagnola]], ''The Astrologer'', c. 1509, with areas such as the dark foreground, the man's bald head, and the tree trunks created by a burin stippling technique.]] '''Stipple engraving''' is a technique used to create tone in an [[Intaglio (printmaking)|intaglio]] print by distributing a pattern of dots of various sizes and densities across the image. The pattern is created on the printing plate either in [[engraving]] by gouging out the dots with a [[Burin (engraving)|burin]], or through an [[etching]] process.<ref name=pankow/> [[Stippling]] was used as an adjunct to conventional [[line engraving]] and etching for over two centuries, before being developed as a distinct technique in the mid-18th century.<ref name=salaman/>
The technique allows for subtle tonal variations and is especially suitable for reproducing chalk drawings.<ref name=verhoogt>{{cite book|title=Art in Reproduction: Nineteenth-Century Prints after Lawrence Alma-Tadema, Jozef Israels and Ary Scheffer|first= Robert|last= Verhoogt |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jSDnRo7YrWwC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Verhoogt,+Art+in+Reproduction&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Xi0NT57ZJOquiQKfntSGBA&sqi=2&ved=0CEQQ6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=crayon%20manner&f=false|page=77|isbn=978-90-5356-913-9|publisher=Amsterdam University Press|year=2007}}</ref>
==Early history== Stipple effects were used in conjunction with other engraving techniques by artists as early as [[Giulio Campagnola]] (c.1482 – c. 1515) and [[Ottavio Leoni]] (1578 – 1630), although some of Campagnola's small prints were almost entirely in stipple.<ref>Mark J. Zucker in Kristin L. Spangenberg (ed), ''Six Centuries of Master Prints: Treasures from the Herbert Greer French collection'', Cincinnati Art Museum, 1993, nos 39 & 40, {{ISBN|0-931537-15-0}}</ref> In Holland in the seventeenth century, the printmaker and goldsmith [[Jan Lutma]] developed an engraving technique, known as ''opus mallei'', in which the dots are punched into the plate by an awl struck with a hammer, while in England the faces of portraits were engraved with stippled dots by [[William Rogers (engraver)|William Rogers]] in the sixteenth century and [[Lucas Vorsterman]] in the seventeenth.<ref name=salaman>{{cite book|title=The Old Engravers of England in Their Relation to Contemporary Life and Art|first= Malcolm C.|last= Salaman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GZh5Bl3_zb8C&pg=PA204&dq|pages=204–07}}</ref>
==Eighteenth century== [[File:Duchess of Richmond, 1775 stipple engraving.jpg|thumb|''The Duchess of Richmond'', a stipple engraving portrait by [[William Wynne Ryland]] after [[Angelica Kauffman]] (1775)]]
An etched stipple technique known as the '''crayon manner''', suitable for producing imitations of chalk drawings, was pioneered in France. Gilles Demarteau used in 1756 goldsmith's chasing tools and marking-wheels to shade the lines in a series of ''Trophies'' designed by [[Antoine Watteau]]. [[Jean-Charles François]] who was a partner of Demarteau further developed the technique and used it to engrave the whole plate. François engraved in 1757 three etchings directly on copper in crayon manner. He then used the technique to etch three plates using different-size needles bound together. Other people who contributed to this new engraving technique included Alexis Magny and Jean-Baptiste Delafosse.<ref name=verhoogt/><ref name=ward>Gerald W. R. Ward, 'The Grove Encyclopedia of Materials and Techniques in Art', Oxford University Press, 2008, p. 153</ref> [[William Wynne Ryland]], who had worked with Jean-Charles François,<ref name=salaman/> took the crayon manner to Britain, using it in his contributions to Charles Roger’s publication ''A Collection of Prints in imitation of Drawings'',<ref name=verhoogt/> and developing it further under the name of "stipple engraving".<ref name=salaman/>
The process of stipple engraving is described in [[Theodore Henry Adolphus Fielding|T.H. Fielding]]'s ''Art of Engraving'' (1841). To begin with an etching ground is laid on the plate. The outline is drawn out in small dots with an etching needle, and the darker areas of the image shaded with a pattern of close dots. As in [[mezzotint]] use was made of ''roulettes'', and a ''mattoir'' to produce large numbers of dots relatively quickly.<ref>Griffiths, 78</ref> Then the plate is bitten with acid, and the etching ground removed. The lighter areas of shade are then laid in with a [[drypoint]] or a stipple graver; Fielding describes the latter as "resembling the common kind, except that the blade bends down instead of up, thereby allowing the engraver greater facility in forming the small holes or dots in the copper". The etched middle and dark tones would also be deepened where appropriate with the graver.<ref name=fielding>{{cite book|last=Fielding|first=T.H.|title=The Art of Engraving|pages=63–64|publisher=Ackerman & Co.|location=London|year=1841}}</ref>
In France the technique fed a fashion for reproductions of red chalk drawings by artists such as [[Antoine Watteau]] and [[François Boucher]]. [[Gilles Demarteau]] etched 266 drawings of Boucher in stipple, for printing in an appropriate [[sanguine]]-coloured ink and framing.<ref name=grif>[[Antony Griffiths|Griffiths, Antony]], ''Prints and Printmaking: An Introduction to the History and Techniques'', pp 81, British Museum Press (in UK), 2nd ed., 1996 {{ISBN|0-7141-2608-X}}; [[A. Hyatt Mayor|Mayor, Hyatt A.]], ''Prints and People'', Metropolitan Museum of Art/Princeton, 1971, no. 587-588, {{ISBN|0-691-00326-2}}</ref> These prints so resembled red chalk drawings that they could be framed as little pictures. They could then be hung in the small blank spaces of the elaborately decorated paneling of residences.<ref>[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/94303/rec/1 Alpheus Hyatt Mayor, ''Prints & People: A Social History of Printed Pictures]'', Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.), 1 January 1971, p. 589</ref> [[File:Gilles Demarteau (after Charles André van Loo) - A group of soldiers standing on the right and looking as one of them is talking to a sailor.jpg|thumb|''A group of soldiers'', in crayon manner technique by [[Gilles Demarteau]] after [[Charles André van Loo]]]]
In England the technique was used for "furniture prints" with a similar purpose, and became very popular, though regarded with disdain by producers of the portrait mezzotints that dominated the English portrait print market. Stipple competed with mezzotint as a tonal method of [[printmaking]], and while it lacked the rich depth of tone of mezzotint, it had the great advantage that far more impressions could be taken from a plate.<ref name=grif/>
During the late eighteenth century, some printmakers, including [[Francesco Bartolozzi]], began to use colour in stipple engraving. Rather than using separate plates for each colour, as in most colour printing processes of the time, such as [[Jacob Christoph Le Blon]]'s three-colour mezzotint method, the different colours were carefully applied with a brush to a single plate for each impression,<ref name=salaman/> a highly skilled operation which soon proved economically unviable.<ref name=pankow>{{cite book|title=Tempting the Palette: a survey of color printing processes|first=David|last= Pankow|publisher=RIT Cary Graphic Arts Press|year=2005 |page=12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8zDi3b3nf3oC&q=yielding+a+single+print#v=snippet&q=yielding%20a%20single%20print&f=false|isbn= 978-1-933360-00-3}}</ref> This method is also known as ''à la poupée'' after the French term for the small cotton pads used for the inking.<ref>[http://www.nga.gov/exhibitions/clrflimpr-tech.shtm NGA Washington]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{commonscat-inline|Stipple engravings}}
[[Category:Engraving]] [[Category:Printmaking]] [[Category:Etching]]

revision.comment: Made one change to make sure that the possessive ('s) wasn't italicised
revision.text:
{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[File:松風荘 フィラデルフィア (4).jpg|thumb|''Sōgetsu-ryū'' classical arrangement]] {{nihongo|'''''Sōgetsu-ryū'''''|草月流|}} is a school of ''[[Ikebana]]'', or [[Japan]]ese floral art.
== History == [[File:Teshigahara Sofu.JPG|thumb|upright|left|The founder Sōfu Teshigahara in 1948]] Sogetsu was founded by [[Sōfu Teshigahara]] in 1927.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikebanahq.org/sogetsu.php|title=Ikebana International|publisher=}}</ref> Sofu's father was an Ikebana master, who taught his son from childhood. Sofu wanted to become a painter, but he found that the possibilities for creative expression in using green materials are endless, just as in painting.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Kadensho, the book of flowers|last=Teshigahara|first=Sofu|publisher=Sogetsu Shuppan Inc.|year=1979|isbn=4-88145-001-8|location=|pages=9–12|quote=|via=}}</ref>
He found that the strict rules of traditional ikebana did not allow individual expression. He broke away from traditional ikebana and formed his school in 1926.<ref name="sogetsu.or.jp">{{cite web|url=http://www.sogetsu.or.jp/e/know/about/timeline/|title=IKEBANA SOGETSU Time-line - Know Sogetsu|publisher=}}</ref> In the beginning, he promoted the school through radio.
As of 2016, there have been four headmasters. Sofu's daughter Kazumi was a gifted artist. She became the second headmaster until she died at age 47. Her elder brother, film director [[Hiroshi Teshigahara]], took over. The current headmaster is Akane, Sofu's granddaughter.<ref name="sogetsu.or.jp"/>
The Sogetsu school is an open-minded and avant-gardist school. The school was one of the first to have English textbooks.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Exploring Ikebana|last=Beunen|first=Ilse|publisher=Stichting Kunstboek|year=2015|isbn=978-90-5856-504-4|location=|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> [[File:Ikebana DSC 9552 (13032184793).jpg|thumb|Free-style arrangement]] A famous saying by Sofu Teshigahara and credo of the Sogetsu school is that Sogetsu can be done by anyone, anywhere, anytime with any kind of material. <ref>{{Cite book|title=Ikebana Sogetsu|last=Teshigahara|first=Hiroshi|publisher=Shufunotomo co., Ltd.|year=1986|isbn=4-07-974618-0|location=|pages=1|quote=|via=}}</ref>
The school is led by Akane Teshigahara, the founder's granddaughter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sogetsu.or.jp/e/akane/profile/|title=IKEBANA SOGETSU Profile - Sogetsu and Akane Teshigahara|publisher=}}</ref> Noted practitioners include Master Instructor Koka Fukushima, whose masterclasses worldwide have received acclaim in floral art circles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/life/2005/08/13/people/koka-fukushima/|title=Koka Fukushima|first=Vivienne|last=Kenrick|date=13 August 2005|publisher=|via=Japan Times Online}}</ref> [[File:Sogetsu-Kaikan-Akasaka-01.jpg|thumb|upright|Sōgetsu Hall headquarters in Tokyo]]
The headquarters was constructed by the architect [[Kenzo Tange]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sogetsu.or.jp/e/know/hall/|title=IKEBANA SOGETSU Sogetsu HQ Building - Know Sogetsu|publisher=}}</ref>
== Styles == ''Sōgetsu'' typically uses either a tall, narrow vase such as one made from a bamboo stem, or a flat, open dish in which the flowers and branches are fixed in a hidden [[kenzan]] spiked support. However, other forms are possible, including highly elaborate creations that fill an entire hall. The arrangements in a tall vase are called Nageire, the once in a shallow container are called Moribana.
One of ''Sōgetsu'''s central ideas is that an arrangement should have three strong elements, each with certain proportions and arranged at a certain angle. But there is considerable latitude to work with whatever materials are available and to express the spirit of the moment.
== Headmasters == * 1st Teshigahara Sōfu ( 勅使河原蒼風), 1900-1979 * 2nd Teshigahara Kasumi (勅使河原霞), 1932-1980 * 3rd Teshigahara Hiroshi (勅使河原宏), 1927-2001 * 4th Teshigahara Akane (勅使河原茜) b. 1960<ref>https://www.sogetsu.or.jp/akane/profile/</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{commonscat-inline}} * [http://www.sogetsu.or.jp/e/ ''Sōgetsu'' official website] * https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z9iUasqPlWc&t=52
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sogetsu}} [[Category:Kadō schools]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5) ([[User:Artix Kreiger|Artix Kreiger]])
revision.text:
'''Tal R''' (born in [[Israel]] in 1967) is an artist based in [[Copenhagen]].
Tal R studied at Billedskolen, Copenhagen, 1986–1988 and at the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts, 1994–2000.
Tal R was born in Israel but moved to Denmark with his family when he was one year old. He graduated from the [[Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts]] in 2000.
Tal R's painting style is described as "kolbojnik", which means "left-overs",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.saatchi-gallery.co.uk/artists/tal_r.htm|title=Tal R|author=Saatchi Gallery|publisher=}}</ref> a [[Hebrew]] word for "jack-of-all-trades."
He has shown work in exhibitions including ''Bicycle Thieves'' at Beret International Gallery in [[Chicago]], ''House of Prince'' at Douglas Hyde Gallery in [[Dublin]], ''The Gallery Show'' at the [[Royal Academy of Art]] in [[London]] and ''Ars Fennica'' at Henna and Pertti Niemisto Art Foundation in [[Helsinki]].
He is represented by [[Victoria Miro Gallery]] in London, Cheim & Read in [[New York City]], [[Tim Van Laere Gallery]] in [[Antwerp]] and Contemporary Fine Arts in [[Berlin]].
Tal R currently teaches at the [[Kunstakademie Düsseldorf]].
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.victoria-miro.com/artists/_16/ Tal R at Victoria Miro] *[http://www.cfa-berlin.com/artists/tal_r/ Tal R at Contemporary Fine Arts Berlin] *[http://www.zachfeuer.com/talr.html Tal R at Zach Feuer Gallery] *[http://www.gerhardsengerner.com/Artists/tr.htm Tal R at Gerhardsen Gerner, Oslo] *[http://www.saatchi-gallery.co.uk/artists/tal_r.htm Tal R at the Saatchi Gallery] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080422054920/http://www.schaefergrafik.dk/tal-r/ Tal R at Schäfer Grafisk Værksted] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100904055039/http://www.litografisk.dk/default.aspx?PageId=311&ArtistId=108&color=red&type=single Tal T at Hostrup-Pedersen & Johansen] *[http://channel.louisiana.dk/video/tal-r-daniel-richter-daniel-richter-tal-r Tal R on Daniel Richter - Daniel Richter on Tal R.] Video interview by [[Louisiana Channel]]. *[http://channel.louisiana.dk/video/tal-r-moon-above-copenhagen Tal R: The moon above Copenhagen.] Video interview by [[Louisiana Channel]]. *[http://danishdox.com/en/tal-r-the-virgin Tal R: The Virgin - A film about visions]. *[http://www.sommergallery.com/#!tal-r/cwuf Tal R Artist Page] at [[Sommer Contemporary Art]] [http://www.sommergallery.com/ Gallery Website]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:R, Tal}} [[Category:Danish contemporary artists]] [[Category:Danish painters]] [[Category:Danish artists]] [[Category:Jewish artists]] [[Category:Israeli painters]] [[Category:Israeli contemporary artists]] [[Category:Israeli artists]] [[Category:Kunstakademie Düsseldorf faculty]] [[Category:Recipients of the Eckersberg Medal]] [[Category:Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts alumni]] [[Category:Artists from Copenhagen]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Other uses|The Late Shift (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | name = The Late Shift | image = The Late Shift by Bill Carter.jpeg | caption = Book cover | author = Bill Carter | country = United States | language = English | publisher = [[Hyperion Books|Hyperion]] | release_date = 1994 | english_release_date = | media_type = | pages = 299 | isbn = 978-1-56282-754-0 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | followed_by = [[The War for Late Night]] }} '''''The Late Shift: Letterman, Leno, and the Network Battle for the Night''''' is a 1994 [[non-fiction]] book written by ''[[The New York Times]]'' media reporter Bill Carter.<!--different [[Bill Carter]] than WP article and writer of Miss Sarajevo--> It chronicles the early 1990s conflict surrounding the American [[late-night talk show]] ''[[The Tonight Show]]''. The book was later made into a [[The Late Shift (film)|film of the same name]] by [[HBO]].
==Contents== The book chronicles the behind-the-scenes corporate battle surrounding American [[late-night talk show]]s, leading up to, and after, [[Johnny Carson]]'s 1992 retirement as host of [[NBC]]'s ''[[The Tonight Show]]''. The book primarily details the power struggle between [[David Letterman]] and [[Jay Leno]] to succeed Carson as the "King of Late Night", NBC choosing Leno over Letterman as the next ''Tonight Show'' host, and Letterman later moving to rival network [[CBS]].
==Cast of characters== The following is a partial list of people featured in the book:
;Major principals * [[Johnny Carson]]: Host of ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' from 1962 to 1992. * [[Jay Leno]]: Permanent guest host of ''The Tonight Show'' since 1987. Chosen by [[NBC]] to succeed Carson as host. * [[David Letterman]]: Host of NBC's 12:30am show ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' since 1982. After being bypassed as Carson's successor in favor of Leno, moves to rival network [[CBS]] in 1993.
;Others * [[Helen Kushnick]]: Leno's tough manager who helps him secure his spot as Carson's successor. Becomes executive producer of ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'', but her fierce tactics eventually force both NBC and Leno to fire her. * [[Peter Lassally]]: Executive producer of ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and later ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]''. Becomes an unofficial counselor to Letterman after Leno is selected to succeed Carson. * [[Michael Ovitz]]: Head of the [[Creative Artists Agency]] from 1975 to 1995. Hired by Letterman to negotiate his move from NBC to another network, studio, or syndicator (eventually CBS). * [[Howard Stringer]]: President of CBS from 1988 to 1995. After several unsuccessful attempts to break NBC's ratings stranglehold on the late night hours, negotiates to bring Letterman to his network. * [[Brandon Tartikoff]]: President of NBC's entertainment division from 1981 to 1991. Instrumental in helping to build NBC's 1980s late night lineup of Carson and Letterman, as well as signing Leno to be Carson's permanent guest host in 1987. * [[Bob Wright]]: President of NBC from 1986 to 2007. Tries to negotiate to keep Letterman on NBC. * [[John Agoglia]]: NBC executive from 1980 to 1998 and supporter of Leno.<ref name=variety>{{cite news|first=Brian |last=Lowry |title=John Agoglia, Top NBC Exec in 'Must-See TV' Era, Dies at 76|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/people-news/john-agoglia-top-nbc-exec-in-must-see-tv-era-dead-at-76-1201138124/ |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher= |date=2014-03-25 |accessdate=2014-04-13}}</ref>
==Reception== In a review of ''The Late Shift'' for ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'', Jon Katz wrote, "[This] is a reporter's book, unfailingly balanced, thoroughly researched, filled with scoops and fresh details. Even though CBS's wooing and winning of Mr. Letterman was the subject of enormous publicity, Mr. Carter's book makes clear that we knew less than we thought about what was really going on."<ref name="katz" /> Katz criticized the book for not going into more depth about Letterman's switch to CBS, writing, "As readable as it is, 'The Late Shift' needed to take a more critical, detached look at the long-term significance of Mr. Letterman's move. A number of questions are not addressed."<ref name="katz" /> He concluded, "'The Late Shift' is nonetheless a powerful story, and ultimately a sad one, filled with casualties as well as winners. Mr. Leno, who has been made to seem a second choice by the very people who elevated him, has been betrayed by his employers in the most basic of ways, and he has not yet recovered."<ref name="katz">{{cite journal|last =Katz| first=Jon|title=The Late Shift|journal=[[The New York Times Book Review]]|volume=99|page=11|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]| date =February 20, 1994 |issn=0028-7806 }}</ref>
Kim Campbell reviewed the book for ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'', and commented, "More than just a play-by-play account of the actions that followed Johnny Carson's 1991 retirement announcement, Carter's well-written book is a look at the history of the late-night franchise, and of the men who host the shows that we would rather watch instead of going to bed."<ref name="campbell" /> Campbell described the book as revealing in its assessment of NBC's decision to pass over Letterman for ''The Tonight Show'', concluding, "Carter's eye-opening book leaves the impression that NBC will be remembered more for its loss of Letterman, than for its role as creator of late-night television."<ref name="campbell">{{cite journal|last =Campbell| first=Kim|title=The Late Shift|journal=[[The Christian Science Monitor]] (Eastern edition)|page=17| date = March 11, 1994|issn=0882-7729 }}</ref>
==Lawsuit== [[Helen Kushnick]], Jay Leno's manager at the time of Carson's retirement who was pushed out following her heavy-handed tactics, filed a $30 million lawsuit against Bill Carter, claiming [[libel]]. Specifically, her case related to a claim that she planted a story about Carson's retirement in a New York City [[Tabloid journalism#As a sensational.2C gossip-filled newspaper|tabloid]].<ref>Fleming, Michael. [http://www.variety.com/article/VR120352.html?categoryid=3&cs=1 "Dish: Fox backing off the gay buss"], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', 21 April 1994.</ref> The then-pending lawsuit was noted in the closing credits of the film, as the Broadway tune "[[There's No Business Like Show Business]]" plays. The lawsuit settled out of court for an undisclosed sum; Kushnick died of cancer in August 1996.<ref>{{cite news| last = Shales | first = Tom | coauthors = | title = Tom Shales on the villains in the Leno-O'Brien fiasco at NBC | work = [[The Washington Post]] | language = | publisher = [[The Washington Post Company]] | date = January 19, 2010| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/01/18/AR2010011803528.html | accessdate = 2010-01-23}}</ref>
==Film adaptation== {{details|The Late Shift (film)}} A film adaption of the book was produced in [[1996 in television|1996]] by [[HBO]], directed by [[Betty Thomas]], and starring [[John Michael Higgins]] as Letterman and [[Daniel Roebuck]] as Leno. The film received seven [[Emmy Award]] nominations in categories including "Outstanding Made for Television Movie",<ref name="orlandoemmy" /> makeup,<ref name="elber" /> casting,<ref name="elber">{{cite news| last = Elber| first = Lynn ([[Associated Press]]) | coauthors = | title ='ER' leads the way with 17 nominations for Emmy Awards | work = [[The Deseret News]]|location=[[Salt Lake City, Utah]] | language = | publisher = Deseret News Publishing Company | page = C5 | date = July 19, 1996 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> writing,<ref>{{cite news| last = Lorando | first = Mark| coauthors = | title = Emmy aberration| work = [[The Times-Picayune]] |location=[[New Orleans, Louisiana]]| language = | publisher = The Times-Picayune Publishing Corporation | page = C1 | date = July 22, 1996 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> and directing,<ref name="orlandoemmy" /> acting.<ref name="orlandoemmy">{{cite news| last = | first = | coauthors = | title =Emmy Nominations | work = [[The Orlando Sentinel]] | language = | publisher = Sentinel Communications Co. | page = A4| date = September 9, 1996 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> For her role in the film as Helen Kushnick, actress Kathy Bates won awards from the [[American Comedy Awards]],<ref>{{cite news| last =Sun-Sentinel wire services | first = | coauthors = | title = Disney cuts a deal on new series | work = [[Sun-Sentinel]] | language = | publisher =Sun-Sentinel Company | page = 5E | date =February 19, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> the [[Golden Globe Award]]s,<ref>{{cite news| last = From Beacon Journal wire services | first = | coauthors = | title =Golden Globe Winners List | work = [[Akron Beacon Journal]]|location=[[Ohio]] | language = | publisher = | page = C9 | date =January 21, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> the [[Satellite Award]]s,<ref>{{cite news| last = City News Service | first = | coauthors = | title = Golden (not Globe) Awards recognize finest in Hollywood| work =[[Daily News of Los Angeles]] | language = | publisher = | page = L10 | date =January 17, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> and the [[Screen Actors Guild Awards]].<ref>{{cite news| last = [[Associated Press]] | first = | coauthors = | title = 'Seinfeld,' 'ER' win Screen Guild Awards| work =[[Telegraph Herald]]|location=[[Dubuque, Iowa]] | language = | publisher = | page = A11| date =February 25, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref> The film was also recognized with an award for "Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Dramatic Specials" from the [[Directors Guild of America Award]]s.<ref>{{cite news| last = | first = | coauthors = | title =People | work = [[Contra Costa Times]]|location=[[Walnut Creek, California]]| language = | publisher = | page = A02 | date =March 11, 1997 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Sequel== A sequel to ''The Late Shift'' called ''[[The War for Late Night]]'', based on [[2010 Tonight Show conflict|the controversy]] involving [[Jay Leno]], [[Conan O'Brien]], ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' and [[NBC]] was released on November 4, 2010.<ref name="lateshift2">{{cite web| url= http://gawker.com/5469767/new-york-times-bill-carter-at-work-on-a-late-shift-sequel| title= New York Times' Bill Carter at Work on a Late Shift Sequel| work=[[Gawker]]| date= 2010-02-11}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== * {{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/01/30/magazine/behind-the-headlines-in-the-leno-letterman-war.html?pagewanted=1 | title=Behind the Headlines in the Leno-Letterman War | first=Bill | last=Carter | newspaper=New York Times | page=628 | date=January 30, 1994 }} *{{cite book|last=Carter|first=Bill|title=Desperate Networks|publisher=Broadway|year=2007|isbn=0-7679-1974-2|pages=333–340}} ;Lawsuit *''Helen Gorman Kushnick v. Disney Book Publishing, Inc., et al.'' (1994) [[Los Angeles Superior Court]] ;Book reviews *{{cite journal|title=The Late Shift|journal=Barron's|issue=|page=66|location = [[Chicopee, Massachusetts]]| date =March 7, 1994|issn=1077-8039 }} *{{cite journal|last =Rosen| first=Jay|title=The Late Shift|journal=[[The New York Times]] (Late New York Edition)|page=C20|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |date =February 22, 1994|issn =0362-4331 }} *{{cite journal|last =Waters| first=Harry F. |title=The Late Shift|journal=[[Newsweek]]|volume=123|issue=|page=62| date = February 21, 1994|issn =0028-9604 }}
==External links== *{{cite news | title=Look Who's Talking: A Media Critic Dishes the Dirt on Leno and Letterman | url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,301115,00.html | publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' | accessdate=2010-01-22 | date=February 11, 1994}}
{{David Letterman}} {{The Tonight Show}} {{LateNiteonNBC}} {{LateShowonCBS}}

page.title: Two Water Mills with an Open Sluice
